message.content:
cs.RO, cs.AI, cs.SY, cs.LG, cs.HC. 

The paper presents a shared control paradigm that uses a data-driven, model-based representation of the joint human-machine system to evaluate potential inputs that the user may wish to provide. This involves using modern computational resources to consider a significant number of potential trajectories at each time step in a control loop. Therefore, the paper is likely to belong to the Robotics (cs.RO) sub-category, as it deals with the operation of complex, dynamic systems in potentially dangerous environments. Additionally, the paper involves the use of machine learning techniques to evaluate potential inputs, which suggests that it could also belong to the Artificial Intelligence (cs.AI) sub-category. The paper also focuses on improving system safety without constraining the user's ability to achieve unspecified behaviors, which suggests that it could belong to the Systems and Control (cs.SY) sub-category. Furthermore, the paper evaluates the efficacy of the shared control algorithm with a human subjects study, which suggests that it could also belong to the Human-Computer Interaction (cs.HC) sub-category. Finally, the paper involves the use of modern computational resources to consider a significant number of potential trajectories, which suggests that it could also belong to the Machine Learning (cs.LG) sub-category.
